questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about non-invasive prenatal testing?

choices.text: It uses cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum
It is used for the diagnosis of trisomy 13, 18 and 21
It can be performed after 10 weeks of gestation
It is done after the routine first trimester ultrasound assessment

questions.solution:
Non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) is used for the screening of trisomy 13, 18 and 21 and Turner's syndrome. It is not a diagnostic test.

It is a novel genetic test that uses cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum for screening of chromosomal anomalies. 

DNA from the fetus is found circulating in the maternal blood in two forms - either inside the intact fetal cells or as cell-free DNA from the breakdown of placental fetal cells. In NIPT, the cell-free chromosome fragments are measured and the quantitative differences from normal fetuses are noted.

NIPT can be performed after 10 weeks of gestation and is recommended after the routine first-trimester ultrasound assessment in high-risk pregnancies or if either 1st or 2nd-trimester screening becomes positive. Its disadvantage is that it is very expensive and it can be used for screening of only a few chromosomal anomalies such as trisomy 13, 18, and 21 and it doesn't analyse the entire karyotype.

questions.text: A pregnant woman has a fetus with Down's syndrome. Triple test done at 15-16 weeks will have ______.

choices.text: Low MSAFP, high hCG, low UE3
High MSAFP, low hCG, high UE3
Low MSAFP,  high hCG, high UE3
High MSAFP, low hCG, low UE3

questions.solution:
The triple test findings in pregnancies with fetal Down’s syndrome are characterized by:

  • Low MSAFP (maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein) levels, approximately 0.7 MoM (multiples of median).
  • Low unconjugated estriol levels, approximately 0.8 MoM.
  • High hCG levels, approximately 2.0 MoM.

The triple test is done between 15-18 weeks for the diagnosis of Down's syndrome. 

Various antenatal screening tests for aneuploidy are as follows:

Dual test (1st trimester) Triple test (2nd trimester) Quadruple test (2nd trimester)
Beta HCG  Beta HCG  Beta HCG 
PAPPA  Unconjugated estriol  Unconjugated estriol 
This can be combined with nuchal translucency by USG MSAFP  MSAFP 
  Serum inhibin A

First-trimester screening with biochemical analytes (↓) PAPP-A and (↑) hCG and USG measurement of NT (↑) can improve the detection rate (87%) of Down’s syndrome. For confirmation, a prenatal genetic study (CVS, amniocentesis or cordocentesis) has to be performed.

Second-trimester screening (quad screening) at 15–18 weeks: (↓) MSAFP, (↓) uE3, (↑) inhibin A and (↑) hCG can detect trisomy 21 in 85% of cases with a false-positive rate of 0.9%. When it is combined with first-trimester screening, the detection rate is increased to 95%.

 

World Down Syndrome Day (WDSD) on March 21 is an important day recognized worldwide, observed by the United Nations since 2012. The theme is "End The Stereotypes." It's a call to action for everyone worldwide to challenge and break down the stereotypes surrounding Down syndrome.

Related Pearl: Prenatal screening for Down’s syndrome

  • USG findings
    • Intrauterine growth retardation (so decreased blood flow)
    • Choroid plexus cysts
    • Increased nuchal translucency >3 mm
    • Hypoplastic nasal bone
    • Congenital heart defects
    • Increased intestinal echogenicity
    • Duodenal atresia
  • Maternal serum markers
    • Decreased: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), unconjugated estriol, pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A)
    • Increased: Human chorionic gonadotrophin (HCG), inhibin, neutrophil alkaline phosphatase
  • Amniocentesis: 14th-18th week of pregnancy
  • Chorionic villus sampling
    • 10th to 12th week of pregnancy: Gives the diagnosis in the first trimester

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the quadruple screening test?
questions.solution:
Inhibin B is not a component assayed under the quad-screening test. Dimeric inhibin-A is evaluated in this screening test.

Quadruple testing is done in the second trimester between 15-21 weeks of gestation. It comprises:

  • Maternal serum AFP
  • Human chorionic gonadotropin
  • Unconjugated estriol (E3)
  • Dimeric inhibin A

The following table summarizes the findings of the quad-screening test in various conditions.

Parameter Trisomy 21 Trisomy 18 Neural tube defect or abdominal wall defect 
MSAFP Low Low High
β hCG High Low Normal
Unconjugated estriol Low Low Normal
Inhibin A High Normal/Low Normal

Various antenatal screening tests for aneuploidy are as follows:

Dual test (1st trimester) Triple test (2nd trimester) Quadruple test
(2nd trimester)

1. Beta HCG 

2. PAPPA (Pregnancy-associated plasma protein A)

This can be combined with nuchal translucency by USG

1. Beta HCG 

2. Unconjugated estriol 

3. MSAFP  

1. Beta HCG 

2. Unconjugated estriol 

3. MSAFP 

4. Serum inhibin 

Related Pearl: Prenatal screening for Down’s syndrome

  • USG findings
    • Intrauterine growth retardation (so decreased blood flow)
    • Choroid plexus cysts
    • Increased nuchal translucency >3 mm
    • Hypoplastic nasal bone
    • Congenital heart defects
    • Increased intestinal echogenicity
    • Duodenal atresia
  • Maternal serum markers
    • Decreased: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), unconjugated estriol, pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A)
    • Increased: Human chorionic gonadotrophin (HCG), inhibin, neutrophil alkaline phosphatase
  • Amniocentesis: 14th-18th week of pregnancy
  • Chorionic villus sampling
    • 10th to 12th week of pregnancy: Gives the diagnosis in the first trimester

The quadruple screening test is ideally done in the second trimester, during 15-20 weeks of gestation. The most accurate values are seen during 16-18 weeks of gestation. 

It is the measurement of maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP), unconjugated estriol, hCG, and inhibin-A. 

In Down's syndrome (trisomy 21) or Edward's syndrome (trisomy 18), quadruple-marker screenings do not provide any added benefit over first-trimester screenings. It is generally used as a stand-alone test if screening is done for the first time in the second trimester or if first-trimester screening is not available.

  Trisomy 21 Trisomy 18 Neural tube defect or abdominal wall defect Trisomy 13/ Patau syndrome
MSAFP Low Low High  Normal
β hCG High Low Normal  Normal
Unconjugated estriol Low Low Normal  Normal
Inhibin A High Normal/Low Normal  High

questions.text:
Results of the quadruple screening test are tabulated below for three congenital anomalies. Choose the correctly matched set.
Parameter 1 2 3
Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP) Low Low High
 Human chorionic gonadotropin (β-hCG) High Low Normal
Unconjugated estriol Low Low Normal
Inhibin A High Normal/Low Normal
questions.solution:
Quadruple testing is done in the second trimester between 15-21 weeks of gestation and involves the following parameters:

  • Maternal serum alpha fetal protein (MSAFP) 
  • β hCG
  • Unconjugated estriol
  • Inhibin A
Parameter Trisomy 21/ Downs syndrome Trisomy 18/ Edward syndrome Neural tube defect or abdominal wall defect 
MSAFP Low Low High
β hCG High Low Normal
Unconjugated estriol Low Low Normal
Inhibin A High Normal/Low Normal

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is an increased level of alpha fetoprotein seen?
questions.solution:
In underestimated gestational age, there is an increased level of maternal serum alpha fetoprotein (MSAFP).

Elevated levels of MSAFP are seen in:

  • Underestimated gestational age
  • Severe oligohydramnios
  • Multifetal pregnancy
  • Neural tube defects
  • Abdominal wall defects- Omphalocele, Gastroschisis
  • Hepatoma
  • Endodermal sinus tumour

Reduced levels of MSAFP are seen in:

  • Overestimated gestational age
  • Overweight mother
  • Gestational trophoblastic diseases
  • Spontaneous abortion
  • Trisomy 18 and 21

questions.text: Increased maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein is detected in a primigravida. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Repeat measurement of MSAFP at a later date

questions.solution:
The next best step is targeted sonography. Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP) levels are only used as a screening test and must be followed by a diagnostic test.

Amniocentesis is a diagnostic test for amniotic fluid AFP measurement. It was once considered the standard for the diagnosis of open neural tube disorders but has been replaced in most centers by targeted sonography.

Defects in fetal integuments, such as ventral wall and neural tube defects, permit fetal AFP to leak into the amnionic fluid. This results in increased MSAFP levels. This is detected on screening performed from 15 to 20 weeks of gestation.

Conditions with elevated MSAFP:

  • Wrong gestational age
  • Neural tube defects
  • Multiple pregnancies
  • Renal anomalies

Conditions with decreased MSAFP:

  • Trisomies (Down's syndrome)
  • Gestational trophoblastic disease.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding alpha fetoprotein?

choices.text: MSAFP is detected at 16-18 weeks of gestation
Diabetic patients have increased AFP levels
MSAFP is unrelated to period of gestation
Lowest fetal AFP is seen around 13 weeks of gestation

questions.solution:
The maternal serum AFP screening is generally performed from 15-20 weeks of gestation. Hence, it is detected in this period.

Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is the major serum protein in the embryo and fetus. It is produced by the yolk sac and fetal liver. 

Option B: Diabetic patients have low levels of AFP. 

Option C: Gestational age influences the MSAFP levels. The maternal serum concentration increases by approximately 15% per week during the second trimester.

Option D: At about 13 weeks of gestation, the AFP concentration in the fetal serum and amniotic fluid are highest, after which it declines. Conversely, AFP is found in steadily increasing quantities in maternal serum after 12 weeks.

questions.text: During genetic counseling, a pregnant woman states that both she and her husband have sickle cell trait. You offer the option of chorionic villus sampling for prenatal diagnosis. What is the best time to perform this procedure?
questions.solution:
The best time to perform chorionic villous sampling is 11-13 weeks.

Chorionic villus sampling:
Study material

Chorionic villi from trophoblastic cells

Time

10 to 13 weeks (transcervically)

10 weeks to term (transabdominally)

Indications

To detect chromosomal abnormalities such as Down syndrome.

To detect inborn errors of metabolism like phenylketonuria.

For DNA analysis in hemoglobinopathies, thalassemia, and sickle cell anemia.
Complications

Abortion (CVS> Amniocentesis)

Limb reduction defects and oro-mandibular defects (when done before 10 weeks)
Drawback

Not suitable for the detection of neural tube defects.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about amniocentesis?

choices.text: Limb reduction defect is a known complication
Approximately 20 to 30 mL is collected for fetal karyotyping

questions.solution:
Limb reduction defect is a complication of chorionic villous sampling. 

Amniocentesis
Study material Amniotic fluid with amniocytes
Time 16-20 weeks
Early amniocentesis

11-14 weeks (associated with increased fetal loss, foot deformities)
Diagnostic indications Sex-linked disorders, karyotyping, inborn errors of metabolism, neural tube defects
Therapeutic indications Abortion induction, decompression of uterus in acute hydramnios, amnioinfusion in oligohydramnios
Procedure

Under direct sonographic guidance, a 20–22 gauge spinal needle is directed into a clear pocket of amniotic fluid while avoiding the fetus and umbilical cord.

Approximately 20 to 30 mL of fluid is collected.
Complication Chorioamnionitis, premature Rupture Of Membranes (PROM), fetal trauma/loss, fetomaternal hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with 6 weeks of amenorrhea and a positive urine pregnancy test. She states her brother had cystic fibrosis and asks if her child might have the same. Which of the following methods would not be useful for prenatal diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
Fetal skin biopsy is not a recommended method of prenatal diagnosis of cystic fibrosis. It is done to detect inherited skin conditions such as:

  • Ichthyosis
  • Epidermolysis bullosa
  • Oculocutaneous albinism

Invasive procedures for prenatal diagnosis of CFTR gene mutations in cystic fibrosis include:

  • Chorionic villus sampling (CVS)
  • Amniocentesis
  • Cordocentesis or percutaneous umbilical blood sampling (PUBS)

questions.text: A G2P1 woman at 35 weeks of pregnancy presents with complaints of decreased fetal movement. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
In case of reduced fetal movements, the first step of management is to do a non-stress test (NST).

Interpretation of NST:

  • Reactive 
    • ≥2 accelerations of >15 beats/minute above the baseline and longer than 15 seconds in duration are present in a 20-minute observation
    • Reassure the patient and send back home
  • Non-reactive - biophysical profile (BPP) has to be assessed.

questions.text: The CTG shown in the image below may be seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The given CTG shows early deceleration which is seen in cases of head compression.

Related Pearl: Deceleration patterns on cardiotocography (CTG)

Early deceleration: seen in head compression

 

Late deceleration: Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency, foetal hypoxia

 

Variable deceleration: Seen in umbilical cord compression

questions.text: A 35-year-old G2P1 at 38 weeks of gestation came to the labor room with complaints of decreased fetal movements. Non-stress test was done and late decelerations were noted. What does this indicate?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of fetal hypoxia. Late decelerations are seen on an NST in this condition.

Deceleration is a decrease in fetal heart rate below the baseline by 15 bpm for more than 15 seconds. Absent variability of FHR with late decelerations is an indication for immediate Cesarean section.  

Related Pearl: Deceleration patterns on cardiotocography (CTG)

Early deceleration: seen in head compression

 

Late deceleration: Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency, foetal hypoxia

 

Variable deceleration: Seen in umbilical cord compression

questions.text: A pregnant woman brings her son to the hospital for routine immunization. While awaiting his turn, she realizes that her seat is stained with blood. She is rushed to the nearby antenatal clinic. Pulse - 96/min, BP - 110/80 mmHg. Vaginal bleeding is noted and her NST is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the NST showing a sinusoidal pattern point towards a diagnosis of vasa previa. 

Vasa previa is a condition where fetal vessels travel within the membranes and overlie the cervical os. Hence, there can be bleeding during cervical dilatation or membrane rupture. 

Fetal mortality is high due to fetal exsanguination. When bleeding is present in vasa previa, an emergency cesarean section is indicated.

Causes of sinusoidal pattern on NST include:

  • Severe fetal anemia - Rh isoimmunisation, vasa previa, fetomaternal hemorrhage, or twin to twin transfusion
  • Opioids - meperidine, morphine, alphaprodine, butorphanol
  • Amnionitis
  • Fetal distress 
  • Umbilical cord occlusion.
